body.p: While conflicts serious enough to require developer relations involvement are rare, it's inevitable that developers will clash to varying degrees. It's essential that the developer relations team find fair and impartial resolutions to inter-developer problems. Although all situations differ and exercising good judgment is necessary, these guidelines are intended to define the most acceptable course of action.

section.title: When should developer relations be involved?

body.p: Developer relations should only be involved in a conflict when other attempts to solve the issue have failed. Developers should attempt polite discussion relating to the matter at hand to resolve conflict between themselves. Developers within a single top level project (TLP) engaged in conflict may wish to consult with the TLP manager. Although TLP managers are not necessarily qualified to resolve personal disputes, technical issues resulting in conflict can often be resolved within the TLP without developer relations involvement. Personal issues should be brought to the ombudsman via ombudsman@gentoo.org. Developer relations may get involved when the above methods have failed. For resolution of technical conflicts spanning more than one TLP, see the section entitled 'Presenting information to management.'

Issues not necessarily related to personal conflict, such as intentional or repeated policy breaches, malicious or abrasive behavior to users or developers, or similar developer-specific behavorial problems should be brought directly to developer relations via devrel@gentoo.org. This should be dealt with on a case-by-case basis by developer relations and may require disciplinary action as defined by the section entitled 'Disciplinary action.'

Often, conflicts between managers and developers will require a decision be made by the management team. To avoid forcing the management team to investigate all the data already processed by developer relations, a condensed summary of the issues at hand as they relate to the decision being made should be presented by developer relations lead(s). It should be totally unbiased and present all factual information from both sides. A recommendation may or may not be made at the discretion of the developer relations manager(s). Recommendations should be strictly limited to the (usually technical) issue at hand and should be reviewed by the developer relations team prior to submission.

Disciplinary action must be decided on a case-by-case basis by the developer relations leads. For the majority of situations requiring disciplinary action, a warning is enough to correct future behavior. If behavior does not improve, a probationary period with revoked access to Gentoo infrastructure of two weeks to one month is appropriate. If upon restoration of access negative behavior re-occurs, removal from the project will be necessary. In extreme cases, suspension or removal may be necessary upon a single offense.

Except in critical situations where immediate action is required, the developer relations leads determine appropriate disciplinary action (if any) based on recommendations of a devrel judicial hearing board, as described in section (2) below. A developer upon whom disciplinary action is so imposed may appeal this action to the Gentoo Top Level Project managers sitting as an appeals board.

Upon removing a developer, the gentoo-core mailing list should be notified. Additionally, the developer relations team and ombudsman should be informed of the issues that led to removing or suspending a developer. The ombudsman should keep a record of this for future reference, which should preferably be stored on a bug. Developers who are removed from the project may not reapply for developer status without first being cleared by the developer relations leads and the ombudsman.

What follows is written as if every complaint will have one or more complainants disputing the actions of one developer. However, it is possible that two or more developers have lodged complaints against each other. In such a case, all such parties are respondents, and as a result of the investigation, hearing, and Developer Relations review, any number of them could be sanctioned for their actions.

Note that Developer Relations does not favor using this procedure for resolving conflicts; resolution by the Ombudsman or by the individual managers is preferred. Consequently, this procedure explicitly allows that if the investigators conclude that a complaint is without merit, and that the motive for the complaint appears to be to harass another developer, then Developer Relations may still convene a hearing. But in this case, the apparent harasser becomes the respondent.

Occasionally, conflicts within the Gentoo community will give rise to complaints which cannot be resolved by the parties involved. These conflicts may arise between developers, or they may arise from user complaints against individual developers. Except in cases questioning technical competency, resolution of complaints against a developer is the responsibility of Developer Relations. Resolution of conflicts among users is outside the scope of this policy.
Most of these complaints are resolved by mediation by the Ombudsman or by the developer's (or developers') top level manager(s) working with the parties involved. But this is not always possible.

When it is not possible to resolve a developer--developer or user--developer conflict by less formal means, Developer Relations opens a formal inquiry of the complaint. This inquiry procedes in two stages: firstly an investigation, then followed by a hearing if necessary.

Complaints are investigated by an investigation board convened for the complaint in question. This board consists of 3 Developer Relations members who are not otherwise involved in the complaint under investigation. This board is responsible for examining all aspects of the complaint, using whatever records are available and discussing the complaint with the parties involved. Although not required, it is highly desirable that the investigators involve the developers' managers and mentors in this process because these individuals should be in a position to provide valuable insight into the situation which gave rise to the complaint.

This investigation serves two purposes. The first is to make very clear to the parties engaged in the dispute just what the facts appear to be, and thus to expedite a settlement. A hearing can result in adverse consequences for all parties involved, and the investigation can help clarify matters so that the hearing can be avoided. The second purpose is to prepare a factual basis for a hearing if a hearing proves to be necessary.

The investigation is similar to an Anglo-American Grand Jury investigation and so is not public. Necessarily, the responding developer and the complainants are aware of the investigation, as also are any other members of the Gentoo developer or user communities who are interviewed or consulted in the course of the investigation. It can happen that the complainant(s) wish to remain anonymous. Such requests are honored, but they are strongly disfavored. And, the complainants forfeit anonymity if (1) the parties cannot resolve the dispute during the investigation, and also (2) the investigators determine that the issues raised are such that the complainants must also act as respondents.

The investigation process collects evidence from various sources, including IRC logs, relevant conversations, but not excluding other sources of information. Evidence collected by the investigation is not limited solely to the investigation board. Evidence may come from third parties, it is the investigation board's responsibility to determine if the evidence is relevant and factual, and if so, it may include that in their results.

Within 30 days of the start of the investigation, if the parties have not yet agreed to a resolution of their dispute the investigation board reports its results to all of Developer Relations. If the board concludes the complaint is without merit and Developer Relations as a whole agrees, this is reported to all parties involved along with supporting information and the board's reasoning. This provides for quick resolution of complaints based on honest mistakes or misunderstandings which did not become apparent earlier in the resolution process. However, if the developers in question to the action do not agree with this conclusion, Developer Relations proceeds with a hearing as described in the next section.

If the investigators conclude that there is reason to believe the complaint has merit, or if the only purpose of the complaint is to harass the responding developer, then Developer Relations convenes a formal hearing into the complaint (but in the second instance, the person initiating the complaint is now responding). The hearing procedure is described in the next section.
The hearing is conducted by a panel consisting of three Developer Relations members who are otherwise not involved in the complaint in question. Specifically, the panel members:

ol.li: Were not involved in the investigation leading up to the hearing, either as investigators or as parties.

Are not Top Level Managers (because of the possible appeal to these managers, unless such requirement is impractical, in which case such a manager is precluded from participating in any subsequent appeal).
Are not predisposed to favor or to disfavor the respondent developer.

body.p: As far as is practical, the hearing is open to the developer community and to the complainants. The complainants and respondent are appropriate participants and unless a complainant explicitly continues to demand anonymity, they are known to each other. The "anonymous complainant" situation raises precedural and credibility issues which are not addressed by this policy. However, if the respondent is unable to answer the complaint because the only evidence supporting the complaint is provided anonymously and the complaining parties remain unwilling to support their complaint to the respondent, due process (fundamental fairness) considerations will require dismissal.
body.note: This is what is meant by "forfeiting anonymity" in the previous section.
body.p: The Developer Relations hearing is similar to other administrative hearings. The judicial panel reviews the investigators' report and takes further testimony as required to reach a decision. During this process, both the respondent and the complainant(s) are invited to present their own cases and to clarify or rebut evidence or testimony as they feel is necessary. This invitation is not a license for either party to take control of the hearing, and it remains the panel's responsibility to run the hearing professionally and fairly.

It is strongly advised that the hearing panel treat appropriate managers and mentors as "expert witnesses" during the evidentiary phase. The manager and the mentor of any developer complainant or respondent are stongly encouraged to add their special insights into the affair.

At the end of the evidentiary phase, the hearing panel makes a formal ruling on the merits of the complaint, and if appropriate recommends further discipliniary action. The findings of the hearing are referred to the Developer Relations leads for further action consistent with these findings.

Both the complainant(s) and the respondent may challenge a member of either board for cause. Such challenges are resolved by Developer Relations, or, in extreme cases, the TLP managers acting as an appeals board.

Neither the investigators nor the hearing panel have "subpoena" authority; they are not empowered to compel participation from any unwilling party, including the developers in question themselves. However, a developer's refusal to cooperate is relevant to the decision process.

ol.li: Developer Relations members who feel they are unable to remain objective in any particular case are obligated to recuse themselves from the hearing board. Such developers are strongly urged to refuse to act as investigators as well, but in exceptional cases this might not be possible.

Malicious complaints are not acceptable. If in the course of conflict resolution it becomes clear that a developer's complaint was brought in bad faith, that itself is grounds for disciplinary action. There is no specific action Developer Relations can take against a user who is acting in bad faith, although referring such a user to the forum moderators and IRC channel operators for action consistent with their authority could well be appropriate.

The intent of the procedings described in this policy is to provide a fair and open framework for resolving conflicts and complaints which arise in the Gentoo community and which cannot be resolved by more informal means. This policy sets out a rather formal procedure for resolving complaints against active Gentoo developers and for recommending sanctions when appropriate.

Because such procedings can have substantial consequences, they must both be fair and appear fair. This requires that all parties --- investigators, the hearing panel, complainants, respondents, and witnesses --- deport themselves as the professionals they are. Once this resolution procedure is invoked for any particular dispute, all participants are required to treat others involved in the case respectfully and courteously. Repeated or egregious failure to do so is itself cause for discipline consistent with the Developer Relations policy of which this is a part: i.e. a hearing panel has the authority to cite hearing participants for contempt.

Although the investigation board may accept evidence collected from third parties, this does not exclude evidence collected by the judicial board. However, it is expected that the judicial board members do not conduct investigations on their own merits, as that would short-circuit the investigative process and circumvent the process this policy describes. To clarify, the judicial board members may submit anecdoctal evidence they have collected, such as comments overheard on IRC, for example,that may not be immediately available to the investigation board. However, they may not conduct investigations on their own.

body.p: Often Gentoo developers go away on vacation, have to take a short leave for University exams, or even go on a honeymoon. While we applaud you for having a life outside Gentoo, we would like to know when you leave and when you are expected to return. When you leave, alert your immediate development group as well as making a devaway entry.

You need to create a file called .away in your /home/you directory. This file will contain the details of your absence and will be reflected at the devaway site. That page is updated once every hour. Upon your return, simply delete the .away file from your home directory.

An extended leave of absence is defined as inactivity for any period of time longer than 60 days. Access to Gentoo infrastructure will very likely be disabled during this time for security reasons. This means that access to cvs and shell access to dev will be affected -- email will likely not. If developer relations is not made aware prior to an extended period of inactivity, after 60 days the developer will be considered retired and any return will be at the discretion of the developer relations leads and the relevant project manager, if applicable.

Retired developers will have their gentoo.org email address removed from Gentoo mailing lists to prevent mail bounces. Retired developers are responsible for resubscribing to public lists with a non-Gentoo email address. Gentoo email addresses for retired developers will remain as forwards for a period of thirty (30) days to allow developers time to transition their mail.
